title: 113_hr4565
content: The "Startup Capital Modernization Act of 2014" increases small issues exemptive authority under the Securities Act of 1933 to $10,000,000 and includes preemption of state laws. The amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 clarifies State enforcement authority regarding registration requirements under section 3(b)(1) and has no impact on other State enforcement actions. The amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 clarifies state jurisdiction over unlawful conduct of intermediaries, issuers, and custodians in transactions described under section 3(b). The amendment clarifies state jurisdiction over unlawful conduct in transactions described under section 3(b) and excludes certain entities from the shareholder cap. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to exclude securities issued under Regulation A from certain provisions if the issuer meets specific requirements. The Securities and Exchange Commission is required to issue a rule within 180 days to implement this amendment. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to exclude securities issued under Regulation A from certain provisions. The exclusion applies to securities issued before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. EXEMPTED TRANSACTIONS. Exempted Transactions under the Securities Act of 1933 are amended to include transactions meeting specific requirements, such as each purchaser being an accredited investor. The Securities Act of 1933 exempts transactions where securities are sold to accredited investors through general solicitation, with verification required. Securities sold under this exemption are not considered part of a public offering. However, the exemption is not available if the seller is the issuer, its subsidiaries, an underwriter receiving compensation from the issuer, or a dealer. The Securities Act of 1933 exempts certain transactions involving accredited investors from being considered part of a public offering. The exemption does not apply if the seller is the issuer, its subsidiaries, an underwriter receiving compensation from the issuer, or a dealer. Additionally, there are specific amendments made to section 18(b)(4) regarding exempt offerings.
